instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BLK_PWM: What is BLK_PWM? BLK_PWM is a typo of BKL_PWM. When you see BLK_PWM assume the poster meant to type BKL_PWM. BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no image. 

The F7700 has 8.6V, and 8.6V on <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>.
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> has 0.02
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.012V
<SIGNAL>BLK_PWM</SIGNAL> = 0.012V

Need help please.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
Stop looking for backlight when missing image.

Do you get voltage at pins 14, and18/19 of J8300?
Check with LCD connected.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message: no power at pin 14/18/19 its like 0.002

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
ok got it up and running going to os bot no back light
Fuse is ok.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
Pins 18/19 MUST get voltage in the first few seconds (when chime).
This voltage is not maintained, if pin 14 will not go high in this time.
And of course, image and backlight are not enabled.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message: hello pin 18/19 has about 3.3 when1st boot.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
"This voltage is not maintained, if pin 14 will not go high in this time."
???

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message: Hello Informaticos, <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> is running 8.5 on both ends <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> has a voltage of 1.5 should be 3.3 right ? you think <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> is bad ?

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
8.5V at <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> means LCD is recognized; there should be also image.

1.5V at PWM is classic when no backlight.
First try PRAM reset 2-3 times.
If still the same, remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and tie together <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message: Pram Didnt work, going to remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and tie <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BLK_PWM</SIGNAL>, if that solve the problem whats the issue then?

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
Do you have now 3V at <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM?
Did you check XW7720?
Post diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and all return resistors.
Look for corrosion at A5 ball of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full" width="168px"]59468[/ATTACH]
there is no xw7702 next to the <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>

threads.title: Macbook AIR 1466 no screen
threads.message:
That bright point between L7701 and <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> is just XW7720!!!
And looks good in your case.

Think a bit more next time, before doing such afirmation...
